attributes.title: How many days rest are required to recover from a night of sleep deprivation

q1.value: Days of rest required after a night of sleep deprivation to recover

q3.value:
Purpose of the study: 
Many companies expect and require their employees to work full night shifts, and then return to work (often in a job that requires them to have good concentration and carry a lot of responsibility) within 1-2 days. Often this period of rest is during the day, and then the employees are expected to return to work that night. We know from research that day sleep is not as effective as night sleep. Some doctors will work 5 nights in a row of night shifts with only 12 hours rest in between, while pilots can do an all night duty, with only one night of rest and then be rostered on to work again the next day. This study investigates the relationship between local nights of sleep (recovery) and physical and mental fatigue. Physical fatigue will be measured through performance on prospective memory tasks, and mental fatigue is measured in  two questionnaires assessing well being.  Specifically my research question is will 3 nights of recovery (7-9 hours of  sleep in a local time zone) improve performance on PM tasks, a reaction time test and self reported ratings of well being (which may include measures such as energy levels, sleep patterns, and general feelings of well being) and return the employees back to their baseline levels (before they undertook the night of sleep deprivation - baseline is measured when an individual has been absent from a night of sleep deprivation for at least 5 nights)

q4.value:
H1a: If provided three nights rest after a night of sleep deprivation, we expect to see a quadratic (u-shaped) trend in shift workers ratings of wellbeing from pre-sleep deprivation to rest day 3: that is a decrease in wellbeing scores with fatigue followed by a recovery of scores with rest. 
H1b: We expect wellbeing scores on rest day 3 to be no different from wellbeing scores pre-sleep deprivation (baseline)

H2a: If provided three nights rest after a night of sleep deprivation, we expect to see a quadratic (u-shaped) trend in shift workers performance on prospective memory (PM) tasks from pre-sleep deprivation to rest day 3: that is a decrease in PM performance with fatigue followed by a recovery of performance with rest. 

H2b: We expect PM performance on rest day 3 to be no different from PM performance pre-sleep deprivation (baseline)

H3a:If provided three nights rest after a night of sleep deprivation, we expect to see a quadratic (u-shaped) trend in shift workers reaction time on a psychomotor vigilance task (PVT) from pre-sleep deprivation to rest day 3: that is an increase in reaction time on the PVT with fatigue followed by a decrease in reaction time with rest. 
H3b: We expect PVT reaction time on rest day 3 to be no different from PVT reaction time pre- sleep deprivation (baseline) 

Predicted Effect: Performance in PM, PVT and ratings of wellbeing will increase as the nights of sleep accumulated increases (to a point where sleep debt is completely recovered) - in this study we are hypothesising that this will be three local nights of full (7-9 hour) sleeps. 

We expect the control group to remain the same throughout the 5 days.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study is a mixed 5x2 (time x treatment) design with repeated measures on the first factor. (I.e all participants participate in all 5 levels of time (within) - but there are two treatment groups - sleep deprived and non sleep deprived (between)) 

Each level (day of the experiment) will have a section dedicated to assessing the participants performance in Prospective Memory, Reaction time and self reported well being. The task in the Prospective Memory section will be the same across all time levels -( the only difference will be a different target pattern to notice on each level and this is in a different order for each participant) the reaction time and wellbeing tasks are the same across all time levels. 

Independent Variables (treatments) night shift worker vs non night shift worker
levels:
1.Baseline (pre sleep deprived) 
2.Sleep deprived (straight after work)
3.Rest Day 1
4.Rest Day 2
5.Rest Day 3

DVs:
PM
RT
Wellbeing questionnaire 1 (fatigue questionnaire)
wellbeing questionnaire 2 (PANAS)

The control group (non night shift workers)
was included to control for practice effects and to increase the internal validity of the study. this will isolate whether night shift workers are improving across the levels because they are getting better at performing the task. If there are no practice effects we expect the performance of the non night shift workers to stay the same across the 5 days without improvement. Whereas the night shift workers should be improving due to recovery of sleep debt.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The population from which the participants will come from is any shift worker that has completed a night shift. This shift worker will have had to have either no sleep or minimal sleep (less than 3 hours) during the shift. Following the night shift the participant will need to have three clear days off in order to participate in the experiment without contaminating the data or results by continuing to work (if a participant has work on day three this is fine as long as its work in the afternoon/ late morning  - i.e the experiment needs to be done while you are still at home resting. If its done by 10am the rest of the day is theirs to do with what they please) 
Recruitment will be done by contacting workplaces or known people who work within workplaces that have night shift work, and gaining expressions of interest. 



The population for the control subjects is men and women of a working age (effort will be made to match to night shift workers for age and gender) that do not participate in night shift work and get an average of 8 hours sleep every night. 

Participants will be rewarded with a voucher to thank them for their time ( $10 NZD pp - efforts are being made to increase this to $20 pp pending funding -potential to increase pp if participant numbers are not met by 3 weeks into participant recruitment) 

Exclusion criteria:
can not fluently read english
are taking medication that compromises concentration 
are under the influence of drugs or alcohol 
do not have a computer or internet access to complete data collection
do not have three days without work after sleep deprivation (night shift group)
do not have four days without night shift work to complete baseline (night shift group)
are not getting 8 hours sleep per night (non night shift group)
do not have five days available to complete the experiment every morning

Coffee and Sleeping pills:
taking sleeping pills/aids (or melatonin) before going to sleep and coffee before doing the experiment are not encouraged as this may affect the results of the study. However if they are crucial to your functioning and a part of your routine that you cannot go without then please record that you have taken it in the space provided in the experiment.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants (50 controls and 50 night shift workers). We will attempt to recruit up tp 120 assuming that some may drop out during the task or not fulfill the inclusion criteria.

q14.value:
time and money are both constraints on this project - the project is due at the end of May which means I only have 1.5 months to two months of data collection time (unless an extension is granted) Massey university funding is $1000 and we are trying to get slightly more ($200) to allow participants to get at least a $10 voucher pp to thank them for their time.

G power was used to determine the sample size for an equivalence test (two single sample t-tests) 
Alpha set at 0.025 (because there are two tests)
Power set to 0.8

This gives N=34 to detect a difference of d=0.5 (decent sized medium effect)

G power was used to determine what kind of sample is needed for a trend analysis. N=50 will allow us to detect an equivalence test effect of d=0.4 

+ this is doubled to include control participants = N=100

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when the required amount of participants are reached, or when we reach the 15th of April (which ever comes first) - unless an extension is granted.

question.value:
there are five levels of treatment, 
these are:
1. Before Shift (Baseline)
2. After Shift (Very Tired - sleep deprived)
3. Rest Day One (Sleep Debt)
4. Rest Day Two (Less Sleep Debt)
5. Rest Day Three (No Sleep Debt)

Wellbeing 1-  PANAS Questionnaire 
Wellbeing 2- Fatigue scale 
Prospective Memory performance - PM (Trivia PM game)
Reaction Time - RT (3 minute PVT)

Two Part Analysis Plan:

Firstly, we are going to look to see whether we have a U-shaped (quadratic) change in scores from pre- sleep deprivation (baseline) to rest day 3. To do this we will do a one-way repeated measures ANOVA and do a trend analysis. We will be looking for a linear trend and a quadratic trend - but hoping that the quadratic trend explains more of the variance (eg has a larger effect size) than the linear trend. This is allowing us to test the idea that fatigue causes a drop in scores which recovers over time. 

Secondly, we will check to see whether baseline and day 3 scores differ (hypothesising that there will be no difference). To do this we will be using equivalence testing (using TOST). 
This trend analysis will tell us whether the change in scores is U shaped but it won't tell us whether things are completely "back to normal" by rest day 3. Whereas this test will. 
We may find that the scores do drop after the night shift and start to recover but do not reach baseline by day 3 - or we might find that they just reach or are better than baseline. 

To do an equivalence test we need to decide our testing bounds (how precise we want to be that a score is the same or what the range is)
we have decided to set our SESOI at 0.5 - this the "leeway" each participant will have on each side away from their baseline score to still count as being "the same" as baseline. This number was chosen to detect a medium effect size for a medium number of participants, as research of this nature struggles to get many participants we did not want to set the SESOI too low and miss detecting  what we are looking for.

The below is the different things we will be measuring:
Wellbeing 1(Fatigue Scale): 
score

Wellbeing 2 (PANAS):
score:

Prospective Memory
Hits 
Misses
RT
False Alarms:

PVT
RT:
False Alarms:

q24.value:
Does taking melatonin/sleeping pill improve the time it takes to recover?
Does sleeping during the day improve/hinder the time it takes to recover?
Is there any difference in results between people that were partially sleep deprived and totally sleep deprived? I.E those who were able to have a 3 hour nap during their shift.

I ask "do you feel rested?/ was your sleep restful" and I am expecting this to be a yes after the 3 days - I am expecting this will correlate with the baseline measure.

name.value: Aggression-ES-A validation: correlations with a trait measure of aggression and gender invariance

analyses.value:
1) Multi-level SEM will be used. Aggression latent variables will be specified at both the within- and between-person level for the Aggression-ES-A and at the between-person only level for the SBQ. The between-person correlation between the between-level Aggression-ES-A construct and the SBQ will be used to evaluate the concurrent validity of the new Aggression-ES-A against a validated trait measure of aggression
2) Multi-level CFA will be used to test gender invariance. This will use a series of increasingly constrained models beginning with configural, then metric then scalar invariance across gender. Changes in CFI, SRMR, and RMSEA will be used to assess invariance at each stage based on Chen's (2007) criteria. If invariance does not hold at any stage constraints will  be iteratively removed until a partially invariant model is achieved. 

References

Chen, F. F. (2007). Sensitivity of goodness of fit indexes to lack of measurement invariance. Structural Equation Modeling: A Multidisciplinary Journal, 14(3), 464–504.

outliers.value: Observations with more than 90% missing data have been removed.

dependent.value:
For 1) The dependent variable is general aggression measured by the Social Behavior Questionnaire (SBQ; Tremblay et al., 1991)
2) The dependent variables are the items of Aggression-ES-A measure (Murray et al., 2020)

References
Murray, A. L., Eisner, M., Ribeaud, D., & Booth, T. (2019). Validation of a brief measure of aggression for experience sampling research: The Aggression-ES-A.
Tremblay, R. E. (2000). The development of agressive behaviour during childhood: What have we learned in the past century? International Journal of Behavioral Development, 24(2), 129–141.

hypothesis.value:
1) Trait aggression will be positively and significantly correlated with aggression measured using the Aggression-ES-A in an ecological momentary assessment design
2) The Aggression-ES-A will show gender invariance at the within- and between-person level

Changes in CFI, SRMR, and RMSEA will be used to assess invariance at each stage based on Chen's (2007) criteria. If invariance does not hold at any stage constraints will  be iteratively removed until a partially invariant model is achieved.

q15.value: The eurozone is ostensibly going through an economic recovery after the worst recession since the Great Depression. Yet despite the positive aggregate economic numbers there remains much variation in who in the crisis-hit countries is experiencing the recovery, the degree of economic optimism when thinking about expectations and opportunities, and who maintains trust in the domestic political system and supranational institutions (i.e. the EU). This is also evidenced by the rise in anti-establishment parties in two of the major Southern European countries that were hard hit by the crisis (Italy and Spain), as well as enduring skepticism of EU-supported policies in Portugal. In this paper we first examine whether citizens actually perceive their country is in recovery. Our main focus is on whether priming the economic recovery since the crisis affects policy attitudes. We assess if respondents exposed to a statement about economic recovery news affects support for social spending and labor market reform, among other policy views. Collection of survey data during this time is relevant in order to gauge information on citizens’ preferences during a period of economic recovery.

q16.value: Our main test is a simple difference-in-means comparisons between the treatment (being exposed to a prime about the economic recovery) and control groups to test the following hypotheses: Treated respondents are expected to express less support for general social spending, taxes, reduce labor regulations, evaluate negatively crisis spending, positively labor reforms, support for the EU, attribution of economic situation to domestic polcies, political efficacy, a preference for a reduced role of the state, and better economic expectations (personal, closest circle, and sociotropic). Moderation effects We will include these moderators as interactions with the treatment, with the general expectations as follows: *Income: We expect that higher incomes will amplify the effects of the treatment. *Current status of being employed: We expect that employed status will amplify the effects of the treatment. *Status of having been unemployed for a long time during the crisis: We expect that larger unemployment spells during the crisis will either be unaffected by or reduce the effects of the treatment. *% of income lost or gained during the crisis period: We expect that the treatment impact will be higher among those who have larger gains in income since the crisis. *Social mobility: We expect the treatment impact to be greater among those who have experienced positive income mobility, and among those who expect upward social mobility in the future. *Economic knowledge. We expect the treatment impact to have a larger impact among a) those who believed that the economic growth rate was negative; b) those who had an overall larger negative perception of the economy and unemployment rate. (See attached PAP for details)

q17.value: Our main test is a simple difference-in-means comparisons between the treatment and control groups to test the hypotheses and expectations described above for each policy question. The expectations are described in Table 1. After initial difference of means tests, we estimate logistic and OLS estimations for the policy preferences (depending on the specification of the dependent variable). The analyses will be conducted with and without covariates as controls. The covariates will be: female gender; categorical education variable; age category; income; employed; labor-market outsider; left-wing ideology; % of income lost or gained during the crisis period. (see attached PAP for details)

attributes.title: Study 1. Semantic vs Episodic memories
attributes.description: We aim to examine to which extent top-down predictions in early visual cortex (EVC) can be related to episodic and semantic memory. In order to do so, we will use a visual occluder and fMRI to measure brain activity on a region of EVC which receives no external stimulation, while the rest of the visual field contains external information that can trigger memory retrieval. Our main goal is to find differential activity patterns within V1 and V2 in the occluded region (Smith and Muckli, 2010) that can be attributed to feedback information based on episodic and semantic memory from the hippocampus and ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC), respectively.

q1.value: FeedBES: Semantic vs episodic information in early visual cortex

q2.value: Javier Ortiz-Tudela, Johanna Bergmann, Matthew Bennett, Lars Muckli, Yee Lee Shing

q3.value: We aim to examine to which extent top-down predictions in early visual cortex (EVC) can be related to episodic and semantic memory. In order to do so, we will use a visual occluder and fMRI to measure brain activity on a region of EVC which receives no external stimulation, while the rest of the visual field contains external information that can trigger memory retrieval. Our main goal is to find differential activity patterns within V1 and V2 in the occluded region (Smith and Muckli, 2010) that can be attributed to feedback information based on episodic and semantic memory from the hippocampus and ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC), respectively.

q4.value:
H1. If episodic and semantic information can serve as source of prediction in EVC, then classification accuracy for object information and scene information will be above chance in the occluded areas of V1 and V2.
- H1a. If the representation of objects necessarily requires the recruitment of the foveal voxels, then classification accuracy for object information should be above chance in foveal subregions of V1 and V2.
- H1b. If the representation of objects can be done independently of the foveal voxels, then classification accuracy for object information should be at chance in foveal subregions of V1 and V2.

H2. If episodic remembering serves as source of prediction through neural reinstatement in EVC, then the degree of pattern reinstatement as indexed by classification decision values will be related to activity in hippocampus more strongly on episodic trials than on semantic trials.
- H2a. If prediction generation is enabled by completion of the missing information (i.e., occluded area) upon exposure to partial stimulation (i.e., full scene with the occluder patch), pattern reinstatement will be more strongly related with activity in CA1 than with activity in other hippocampal subfields.

H3. If semantic remembering serves as source of prediction through neural reinstatement in EVC, then the degree of pattern reinstatement as indexed by classification decision values  will be related to activity in vmPFC more strongly on semantic trials than on episodic trials.

H4. If HC and vmPFC are differentially involved in the retrieval of episodic and semantic memories, then the relation between classification decision values in EVC and activity in those distant regions will be modulated by memory condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
## Study design 
### Stimuli. 
Our stimulus set consists of pairs of scenes and objects images. All of the scenes’ images depict common indoor locations and the objects images depict commonly used items. The whole stimulus set is divided into two subsets: 

- Episodic set: Eight different scene-object combinations will be used to generate episodic memories. The pairings were built so that the two elements (i.e., scene and object) had a minimal semantic relation (e.g., "TV" in a "bathroom").

- Semantic set: Another set of eight different scene-object combinations will be used for the semantic conditions. The pairings in this subset were built so that the objects had a strong semantic relationship with the scenes (e.g., "bathtub" in a "bathroom").

Every participant will be assigned to a given combination of objects and scenes and these combinations will be counterbalanced across participants so that across the entire sample every object was seen in every possible location. 

### Procedure. 
#### Day 1: 
_Learning phase_: Participants will be presented with three learning blocks in which the pairs from the episodic set will be shown sequentially and repeated ten times. Participants will be instructed to memorize as many details as possible from the entire scene and to pay special attention to the target object (i.e., the object that will be placed on the bottom-right corner of the scene). At the end of each block, the acquisition of the scene-object pairings and the memory for the precise object position in the scene will be tested. 

After completing the learning blocks, participants will be given a printed version of the scenes with a white patch occluding the target area and they will be asked to draw the target objects from memory.

Finally, at the end of the session, participants will perform one block of the scanner task (equivalent to one scanning run) to familiarize them with the timing and the structure of the task. The only difference between this familiarization block and the scanner blocks is that a trial-by-trial vividness rating will be performed. After every trial participants will be asked to report their subjective vividness of retrieved object on a four points scale.

#### Day 2 (_24h after Day 1):

_Pre-scan phase_: Participants will be shown the scenes in the semantic set. They will be asked to select among the object studied on Day 1 the one that best fits each scene (i.e., those that would typically be found in each location in the real world). If they select the wrong object, the correct answer will be provided by the experimenter.

_Scanning phase_: We will use a 3 Tesla MR scanner (SIEMENS Prisma) to acquire functional and anatomical brain images. In order to avoid fatigue and prevent unwanted movements, we will distribute our scanning sequences over two sessions with a 5-10 minutes break in between; participants will be allowed to use the toilet, stretch and walk to prevent neck and shoulders stiffness. Both scanning sessions will include one T1 weighted anatomical image, 2 object retrieval runs and 1 visual mapping run. In addition, the first session will include a high resolution scan of the hippocampal area and the second session will include a sensory template run. 

- _Object retrieval task_: This task will consist of two types of trials: episodic and semantic. On episodic trials participants will be presented with the scenes studied during the learning phase; on semantic trials, participants will be presented with the scenes from the semantic set. In both types of trials, a white patch will occlude the bottom right corner of the image thus hiding the target object; participants will be asked to vividly retrieve either the studied object (i.e., episodic trials) or the semantically matching one (i.e., semantic trials). The different trial types will be randomly intermixed.
- _Retinotopic mapping_: we will map our participants' visual cortex activity to on-screen visual stimulation varying either in eccentricity or in polar angle. 
- _Target mapping_: we will use contrast-reversing flashing checkerboards to functionally locate the voxels in V1 and V2 responding to our target region.
- _Moving bars_: we will use contrast-reversing moving checkerboards bars to allow for pRFs computation. pRFs will be used to fine tune the target area extracted from the target mapping block.
- _Sensory templates_: for all of our stimuli (scene-object combinations) we will assess stimulus-specific activation maps in V1 and V2 by presenting them sequentially in the context of a 1-back task. 
_Post-scan phase_: Participants will perform a memory test (identical to that in the learning phase) that will check for scene-object associations (both for episodic and semantic pairings). In addition, in the case of the episodic trials, we will check for correct positioning of the objects in the scene.

q9.value: Trial order transitions will be optimized (OptimizeX) to allow for maximum separation of trial types.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data from three participants has already been acquired to serve as pilot to verify stimulation procedures and preprocessing scripts; no statistical analyses have been run for these three participants. Since no further changes, adjustments or improvements are required in the paradigm after examination of that data set, we will include them in the final report of results.

question.value: Young adults (aged 18-30 years) will be recruited through advertisements placed across the three campi of the Goethe University in Frankfurt. In exchange for participation, they will receive course credits (for psychology majors) or honorarium (for all other majors).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 participants

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect an effect size of .46 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: Recruitment efforts will continue until the required sample size of 40 valid participants is reached (see exclusion criteria).

question.value:
Our manipulated variables will be EVC regions of interest (ROI) and trial type. 
- EVC ROIs: We will use functional retinotopy to delineate each participants' V1 and V2 and a contrast-reversing checkerboard stimulation procedure to map brain voxels onto two on-screen sites (i.e., periphery vs fovea). We will therefore have four different brain ROIs: v1_periphery, v2_periphery, v1_fovea and v2_fovea.

- Sources ROIs: For the hippocampus, we will use the high resolution hippocampal scan collected for each participant to perform an automatic segmentation of the hippocampal subfields (ASHS) which will then be combined into a single mask. For the vmPFC we will use a standarized functional mask (Neurosynth).

- Trial type: The two levels of this variable are episodic or semantic (see Study design for more).

# Behavioral measures: 
- Memory performance: proportion of pairings accurately remembered both in Day 1 (final proportion) and on Day 2 (post-scanning test). 
- Manual drawings: participants will draw the target objects in Day 1 and these will be coded as correct or incorrect retrievals.
- Vividness ratings: The subjective retrieval vividness reported on a 4 points scale after every trial.

# Neural measures: We will use percentage of change in BOLD signal to train and test linear SVMs for item-specific classifications. Our statistical analyses will be conducted on classification accuracy.

Classification performance will be averaged across cross-validation folds to obtain a single measure of classification performance for every item. Single-item (i.e., scenes or objects) accuracy will be averaged across items to obtain a measure of either scene information or object information.

In order to test H1, independent t tests will be run to test for above change (.50) classification performance for our binary classifiers.

In order to test H2 and H3, trial wise correlations (as in Rissman, Gazzaley and D’Esposito, 2004) will be run between classification decision values and beta estimates for the hippocampal and vmPFC ROIs.

In order to test H4, a 2-way repeated measures ANOVA will be run with memory condition (i.e., episodic vs semantic) and ROI (i.e., HC vs vmPFC) as within-participants factors.

Although the vividness rating question is included mainly to ensure participants’ engagement during the familiarization task, the average reported ratings will be used to relate brain-based pattern reinstatement with subjective feelings of vividness.

q21.value: We will declare p values below .05 as indexing results that are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
We will exclude data from participants who do not successfully complete any of the phases. The criteria for exclusion for each phase are: 

- Learning phase: Participants unable to learn the scene-object pairings (cut-off 8 out of 8 correct) or unable to report the appropriate object location (cut-off 8 out of 8 correct).

- Scanner phase: Participants with movement above 3mm in any of the spatial axes (x,y,z) or those for which a proper retinotopic map was impossible to obtain.

q23.value: Participants that are unable to successfully complete any of the phases will be excluded from the study and replaced with new ones.

q24.value: In order to look for unforeseen correlations between EVC activity and other distant brain regions as function of type of memory retrieval, we will run a psychophysiological interactions (PPI) analysis with our ROIs in the EVC as seeds. In addition, in order to get a more fine-grained measure of source-regions for memory reinstatement, we will perform a whole brain univariate contrast as in (Bosch et al., 2014) with classification decision values as a parametric regressor.

q25.value: We will also collect a set of covariate tests (i.e., spot-a-word, digit symbol, VVIQ and a general episodic memory performance task from Murray et al., 2015) that, although they will not be part of this study, will be later on used to run a between studies analysis. These tests will include measures of general cognitive performance such as spatial memory ability, fluid and crystallized intelligence or general emotional status such as depression.

attributes.title: Investigating the Role of the Amygdala in Pre-processing Emotion and the Direction of Attention

q1.value: Investigating the Role of the Amygdala in Pre-processing Emotion and the Direction of Attention in Temporal Lobectomy Patients

q3.value: Evidence has come to light in the past few years that highlights the existence of a secondary visual pathway. This proposed pathway runs parallel to the main visual pathway (from the retina to the primary visual cortex) and passes information from the retina to the superior colliculus, pulvinar, and crucially the amygdala. This pathway supposedly processes threat-related and emotionally relevant stimuli. However, more evidence is needed to determine the temporal dynamics of this pathway, the type of stimuli it processes, and to further support its existence. Therefore we will conduct a dot-probe experiment, measuring the response time and accuracy to targets that follow either an emotional or a neutral face. EEG data will be recorded during this experiment. We will test 3 groups - the first group will be scheduled to undergo a temporal lobectomy including the removal of the amygdala, the second will be scheduled to undergo a temporal lobectomy without the amygdala, and the third will be healthy controls. Groups 1 and 2 will be tested before and after surgery. The combination of EEG recordings and testing on a sample without an amygdala will allow us to determine what this proposed pathway is processing, the time rate at which it is processed, and if this pathway feeds into the direction of attention.

q4.value:
Note - the three populations will be referred to as amygdalectomy (or AMY - those who have surgery to remove the temporal lobe and the amygdala), temporal lobectomy (or TLE - those who have surgery to remove the temporal lobe minus the removal of the amygdala) and healthies.

Behavioural Hypotheses
1. healthy, pre-surgery AMYs, and pre/postTLEs will show an attentional bias (faster RT and more accurate responses) for targets appearing after fearful faces (fear-valid targets), compared to after either of two presented neutral faces (control).
2. healthy, preAMYs, and pre/postTLEs will show an attentional deficit (slower RT and less accurate responses) for targets appearing after neutral faces when a fear face is also present (fear-invalid targets), compared to after control.
3. postAMYs will not show an attentional bias for fear-valid targets that are contralateral to their lobectomy site (they will respond as rapidly and as accurately as to targets that follow after two neutral faces).
4. postAMYs will not show an attentional deficit for fear-invalid targets contralateral to lobectomy site  (they will respond as rapidly and as accurately as to targets that follow after two neutral faces).
5. postAMYs will perform as the other groups (hypotheses 1 & 2) for targets that appear ipsilateral to their surgery site.
6. Reaction time and accuracy accross all groups will be mediated by anxiety (high anxiety people will show a greater attentional bias to fear-valid targets than low anxiety, and high anxiety people will perform slower/less accurately on fear-invalid trials compared to low anxiety people). 

EEG-Related Hypotheses
7. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced N170 response for fear compared to neutral faces.
8. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced N2PC response for fear compared to neutral faces.
9. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced P1, N1, and P2 for fear-valid targets (compared to targets following neutral)
10. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced N170 for fear faces contralateral to the lobectomy site (compared to neutral contralateral, and compared to the other groups)
11. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced N2PC for fear faces contralateral to the lobectomy site (compared to neutral contralateral and compared to the other groups)
12. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced P1, N1, or P2 to fear-valid targets (compared to fear-invalid targets) contralateral to the lobectomy site 
13. post-AMYs will respond as normal (hypotheses 7-9) to  fear-valid faces (compared to fear-invalid)  ipsilateral to lobectomy site
14. the N170 for all groups will be mediated by anxiety, such that high anxiety groups will have a more enhanced N170 than low anxiety
15. the N2PC will be moderated by anxiety, such that high anxiety groups will have a more enhanced N2PC than low anxiety

question.value:
The presented type of stimuli will vary on several factors, these include:
Emotion - fearful or neutral faces will be presented
Gender -  male or female faces will be presented
Gabor orientation - Gabor targets will be presented with either horizontal or vertical gratings
Side - Emotional/neutral faces will be presented to the left or right of a fixation point, and the following target (Gabor) will be presented to either the left or right of fixation.

Anxiety, social anxiety, and social cognition will be measured with the Beck Anxiety Index (BAI), the Leibowitz Social Anxiety Scale (LSAS) and a social cognition portion of the the Advanced Clinical Solutions for WAIS-IV and WMS-IV (ACS). 
Behaviourally, a response to the Gabor target will be measured (participants will respond whether it appeared with horizontal or vertical gratings). Correct responses and response time will be measured.
EEG data will be recorded, with triggers marking the onset of faces and the onset of targets.

To analyse ERPs, EEG data for each participant for all trials of one condition will be averaged together. These condition averages will then be averaged together with the data for all other participants from that group. This will create one ERP for each condition, which represents the average for all trials for all participants.

Behavioural data (testing hypotheses 1-6):
Mean reaction time to targets will be calculated for each participant group for Fear Valid and Fear Invalid (for both left and right). Accuracy (proportion of correct responses) for each condition will also be calculated.

Testing H1 - H5
A 3-way between groups ANOVA: 9 (Group: healthy, preTLE left, preTLE right, post TLE left, postTLE right, preAMY L, preAMY right, postAMY left, postAMY right) x 3 (Stim: Fear-valid, Fear-Invalid, Neutral) x 2 (target location: Left, Right) will be conducted for both accuracy and reaction time. 

Testing H6
A regression analysis will be used to examine the relationship between anxiety level and reaction time (collapsing across all other factors). This will be repeated for anxiety level and accuracy. 


EEG data (hypotheses 7-15):
ERPs will be computed for each participant group for each condition. ERPs will be created from electrodes surrounding the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes (however if preliminary analysis reveal differences at other locations these locations will also be explored).

Preliminary t-tests will be conducted to determine significant differences in ERPs at time points e.g. ~140-190ms (N170) and ~200-400ms (N2PC). T-tests will also be conducted at time points identified as significant in preliminary analysis (exploratory). 

Testing H7-13
Each of the following ANOVAs will be conducted to examine differences in ERP amplitude (as measured in microvaults).

A 4-way between groups ANOVA: 4 (Group: TLE left, TLE right, AMY left, AMY right) x 2 (Surgery time: pre, post) x 3 (Stimuli: fear-valid, fear-invalid, neutral) x 2 (Stim location: left, right)

A 3-way between groups ANOVA: (Group: healthy, pre TLE left, pre TLE right, pre AMY left, pre AMY right) x 3 (Stimuli: fear-valid, fear-invalid, neutral) x 2 (Stim location: left, right)

A 3-way between groups ANOVA: (Group: healthy, post TLE left, post TLE right, post AMY left, post AMY right) x 3 (Stimuli: fear-valid, fear-invalid, neutral) x 2 (Stim location: left, right)

All 3 ANOVAs will be performed for each ERP of importance as mentioned in the hypotheses (the N170 and N2PC in response to faces, and the P1, N1, and N2PC in response to targets). 


Testing H14-15
A regression analysis will be used to examine the relationship between ERP amplitude and anxiety (for the N170, and the N2PC).

q21.value: The p-value cut-off for significance will be set at p < .05. Multiple hypotheses are being compared, which could inflate the chance of a type 1 error. A correction could be applied to account for this. However, the population of interest is so rare and small in size that any p-value corrections (such as bonferroni) could be overly restrictive.

q22.value: EEG data will be filtered between a range of 0.18 (high-pass) and 40 (low-pass) with a notch filter at 50Hz to account for the frequency of Australian electrical mains. To flag for epochs contaminated by muscle movement, a limit of 80mV will be set.

registration_responses.q1: Investigating the Role of the Amygdala in Pre-processing Emotion and the Direction of Attention in Temporal Lobectomy Patients
registration_responses.q3: Evidence has come to light in the past few years that highlights the existence of a secondary visual pathway. This proposed pathway runs parallel to the main visual pathway (from the retina to the primary visual cortex) and passes information from the retina to the superior colliculus, pulvinar, and crucially the amygdala. This pathway supposedly processes threat-related and emotionally relevant stimuli. However, more evidence is needed to determine the temporal dynamics of this pathway, the type of stimuli it processes, and to further support its existence. Therefore we will conduct a dot-probe experiment, measuring the response time and accuracy to targets that follow either an emotional or a neutral face. EEG data will be recorded during this experiment. We will test 3 groups - the first group will be scheduled to undergo a temporal lobectomy including the removal of the amygdala, the second will be scheduled to undergo a temporal lobectomy without the amygdala, and the third will be healthy controls. Groups 1 and 2 will be tested before and after surgery. The combination of EEG recordings and testing on a sample without an amygdala will allow us to determine what this proposed pathway is processing, the time rate at which it is processed, and if this pathway feeds into the direction of attention.
registration_responses.q4:
Note - the three populations will be referred to as amygdalectomy (or AMY - those who have surgery to remove the temporal lobe and the amygdala), temporal lobectomy (or TLE - those who have surgery to remove the temporal lobe minus the removal of the amygdala) and healthies.

Behavioural Hypotheses
1. healthy, pre-surgery AMYs, and pre/postTLEs will show an attentional bias (faster RT and more accurate responses) for targets appearing after fearful faces (fear-valid targets), compared to after either of two presented neutral faces (control).
2. healthy, preAMYs, and pre/postTLEs will show an attentional deficit (slower RT and less accurate responses) for targets appearing after neutral faces when a fear face is also present (fear-invalid targets), compared to after control.
3. postAMYs will not show an attentional bias for fear-valid targets that are contralateral to their lobectomy site (they will respond as rapidly and as accurately as to targets that follow after two neutral faces).
4. postAMYs will not show an attentional deficit for fear-invalid targets contralateral to lobectomy site  (they will respond as rapidly and as accurately as to targets that follow after two neutral faces).
5. postAMYs will perform as the other groups (hypotheses 1 & 2) for targets that appear ipsilateral to their surgery site.
6. Reaction time and accuracy accross all groups will be mediated by anxiety (high anxiety people will show a greater attentional bias to fear-valid targets than low anxiety, and high anxiety people will perform slower/less accurately on fear-invalid trials compared to low anxiety people). 

EEG-Related Hypotheses
7. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced N170 response for fear compared to neutral faces.
8. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced N2PC response for fear compared to neutral faces.
9. Healthy, pre/post TLE, preAMY will show an enhanced P1, N1, and P2 for fear-valid targets (compared to targets following neutral)
10. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced N170 for fear faces contralateral to the lobectomy site (compared to neutral contralateral, and compared to the other groups)
11. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced N2PC for fear faces contralateral to the lobectomy site (compared to neutral contralateral and compared to the other groups)
12. post-AMYs will not show an enhanced P1, N1, or P2 to fear-valid targets (compared to fear-invalid targets) contralateral to the lobectomy site 
13. post-AMYs will respond as normal (hypotheses 7-9) to  fear-valid faces (compared to fear-invalid)  ipsilateral to lobectomy site
14. the N170 for all groups will be mediated by anxiety, such that high anxiety groups will have a more enhanced N170 than low anxiety
15. the N2PC will be moderated by anxiety, such that high anxiety groups will have a more enhanced N2PC than low anxiety

attributes.title: Trauma Identity IAT & Response to Variable-length CPT

q1.value: Evaluating Implicit Trauma Associations as Predictors of Treatment Response to Cognitive Processing Therapy for Active Duty Military Personnel

q2.value: Kristen P. Lindgren, Anna Jaffe, Jennifer Wachen

q3.value:
There is burgeoning interest in the role of implicit cognitive processes (i.e., cognitive processes that are fast, reflexive, and potentially less controllable) in psychopathology, particularly because these processes may predict different outcomes than do self-report and may be less vulnerable to demand effects than self-report measures. Further, theories of psychopathology, including theories of PTSD, posit that changes in implicit cognitions are crucial for the development and maintenance of psychopathology. While measures have been developed to assess implicit cognitions related to psychopathology, including PTSD, few studies have evaluated these cognitions in clinical samples and even fewer have evaluated changes in these cognitions over the course of interventions (see Teachman, Marker, & Smith-Janik, 2008, JCCP, for one of the rare exceptions). The proposed study will address gaps by evaluating implicit cognitions related to PTSD (i.e., implicit associations about the self and being traumatized, which we term implicit trauma associations) in a sample of active duty military who participated in a clinical trial of variable length Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT).

A measure of implicit trauma associations (the trauma self IAT) was validated in a previous study (Lindgren et al., 2013, JBTEP). Lindgren et al. found that the trauma self IAT had adequate psychometrics and predicted self-reported post-traumatic stress (PTS) symptoms even after controlling for trauma exposure and self-reported trauma-related cognitions among a sample recruited through the Project Implicit research website (a self-selected sample who self-reported a range of trauma exposure and PTS symptoms). Despite these promising findings with a non-clinical sample, there is a need for additional validation of a trauma-focused IAT and understanding of the role of implicit cognitions in treatment. First, we wish to understand whether individuals’ baseline trauma self IAT scores predict their response to PTSD treatment (in this case, variable-length CPT). Doing so in a sample that is receiving CPT is particularly opportune because a core aim of CPT is to help clients explicitly shift trauma-related cognitions about the self to be more adaptive (i.e., flexible, balanced, realistic).  We consider this question to be exploratory. On the one hand, we could imagine that a higher IAT score at baseline might predict worse response to treatment because it signifies a more rigid trauma self-concept (which may be less responsive to treatment) and greater PTSD severity. On the other hand, we could imagine that a higher IAT score at baseline might predict greater response to treatment because CPT might be an excellent match for individuals with this particular vulnerability and these individuals have greater room for improvement. Second, it is also important to evaluate whether trauma self IAT scores change as a function of the intervention and whether changes in IAT scores predict changes in PTSD symptoms. This will help determine the malleability of the implicit trauma associations and their sensitivity to or prediction of changes in symptoms. Finally, it is unknown whether residual implicit trauma associations following treatment (i.e., IAT scores at 1-month follow up) predict return of symptoms over time (i.e., 3-month f-up), an important question to determine whether the associations serve as a vulnerability marker for potential relapse.

q4.value:
RQ1a: Are baseline IAT scores correlated with baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5), general trauma exposure (# traumatic life events on LEC), military trauma exposure (DRRI scores) and depression (score on the PHQ-9)?
i.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will be positively correlated with PTSD symptoms (replicating Lindgren et al., 2013) and the PHQ-9 (novel)
ii.	Hypothesis: Consistent with Lindgren et al. (2013), IAT scores will not be significantly associated with general trauma exposure (# events on LEC) or military trauma exposure (DRRI)

RQ1b. Do baseline IAT scores predict baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and depression (PHQ-9), even after controlling for gender and trauma exposure (# events on LEC), which are established predictors of PTSD symptoms? 
iii.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will positively predict incremental variance in baseline PTSD symptoms (replicating Lindgren et al., 2013) 
iv.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will positively predict incremental variance in baseline depression symptoms 

RQ1c: Do IAT scores at 1-month follow up (post-treatment IAT scores) differ as a function of whether or not individuals still meet criteria for PTSD or depression
i.	Hypothesis: Post-treatment IAT scores will be lower among individuals who no longer (vs. still) meet criteria for PTSD 
ii.	Hypothesis: Post-treatment IAT scores will be lower among individuals who no longer (vs. still) meet criteria for depression

RQ2a. Do baseline IAT scores predict response to CPT above and beyond baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)?
i.	Exploratory (double-sided hypotheses are offered): 
- Higher IAT scores (i.e., stronger traumatized-me associations) may predict worse treatment outcomes because individuals may have more rigid trauma self-concept and PTSD symptoms
- Higher IAT scores may predict better treatment response because CPT may be a good match for individuals with this vulnerability


RQ3a: How do IAT scores change following treatment?
i.	Hypothesis: IAT scores at 1-month follow up will be significantly lower than IAT scores at baseline
ii.	Exploratory: Evaluate whether changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) vary as a function of treatment length.  One might expect smaller decreases for those who were in treatment longer b/c those individuals took longer to respond to treatment. Alternatively, one might expect larger decreases b/c those individuals had more exposure to cognitive restructuring targeting negative beliefs about the self in relation to traumatic events, which could lead to larger decreases in trauma self IAT scores.   

RQ3b: Do changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) predict changes in PTSD and depression over time (baseline, 1-month, 3-month follow up)?
iii.	Hypothesis: Reductions in IAT scores will be associated with reductions in PTSD symptoms and depression

RQ3c: Do residual IAT scores (i.e., IAT scores at 1-month follow up) predict increased PTSD symptoms at 12 weeks?
i.	Hypothesis: Higher 1-month IAT scores will be associated with greater increases in PTSD symptoms from 1-month to 3-month follow up

q11.value:
Data are being shared with Drs. Lindgren and Jaffe through an agreement with the STRONG STAR Consortium. In order to obtain access to the data, Drs. Lindgren and Jaffe, and their other key collaborators (Drs. Teachman and Kaysen) had to complete a request that detailed the aims/goals of the study, their specific research questions and hypotheses.  Drs. Wachen, Peterson, and Resick sponsored their request to STRONG STAR. Those research questions and hypotheses were approved by the STRONG STAR Consortium as described here. Drs. Lindgren and Jaffe did not receive the data until after that approval.

question.value:
All diagnostic clinical interviews were conducted by an independent evaluator (IE). IEs participated in four stages of training: relevant readings, didactic instruction with an expert in the field, mock interviews with co-workers, and co-rating exercises with previously taped assessments. After the completion of training, all IEs engaged in weekly calibration exercises to ensure that they continued to meet high quality standards. Any drift in scoring (i.e., failure to match decisions about PTSD diagnosis or a discrepancy in total score with the trainers) was brought to the attention of the IE so that the problem can be corrected in future assessments. 

Aside from the weekly administration of the PCL-5, DSI-SS, TRGI, and the PHQ-9, longer assessments, including diagnostic assessments and secondary measures, occurred prior to treatment, and 1 month and 12 weeks after the final therapy session. The assessment measures consisted of a battery of measures that have been used in the STRONG STAR Multidisciplinary Research Consortium studies to fully assess and appreciate complex symptomatology in this patient population, plus a number of study-specific measures. 

One of the original trial outcome variables was the distribution of the number of sessions needed to reach good end-state functioning, and the number of participants who never reached that goal. Any participant who stopped treatment early due to reaching good end-state was considered a treatment completer. If participants stopped prior to reaching a good end-state, they were considered “treatment drop-outs” unless they reached 24 sessions, at which time they would be considered non-responders. Participants were considered “treatment drop-outs” after two weeks of missed sessions without contacting their therapist. Regardless, all participants were asked to continue with assessment at 1 month and 12-weeks after they dropped out of treatment, so they only were considered a “study drop-out” if they stopped completing assessments.

q13.value: The ultimate N for the trial was 130. Data collection was smaller than originally planned (targeted N was 200) due to delays in data collection, which stemmed from delayed IRB approvals. It was determined that a smaller sample size would allow the trial research team to answer their research questions (see rationale below), so the funding agency agreed to a reduction in proposed sample size.

q14.value: Our sample size was determined based on power analyses for the larger clinical trial. For an analysis of variance comparing four groups of roughly equal size (early completers [< 12 sessions], normal completers [12 sessions], late completers [> 12 sessions], and non-responders [24 sessions without research good end state]), power with total N = 130 is .80 if Cohen’s f = .30, slightly larger than his convention for a “medium” effect. Survival regression analysis has power = .80 to detect a hazard ratio of 1.75, representing a different in recovery rates of about 15-20%.

question.value: None.

1. Demographics and Military Service Characteristics –baseline 
2. Life Event Checklist (LEC) - baseline 
3. Implicit Association Test – baseline and 1 month-follow up 
4. Clinician Administered PTSD Scale (CAPS-5) – baseline, 1 month, 3 month
5. PTSD Check List for DSM-5 (PCL-5)- all available time points (baseline, treatment [sessions will vary as a function of participant], 1 month, 3 month) 
6. Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) – all available time points (baseline, treatment [sessions will vary as a function of participant], 1 month, 3 month)

Life Event Checklist (LEC) -- summary variable of total # of different kinds of trauma experiences

Implicit Association Test - D1 scores will be calculated via the instructions from Greenwald et al., 2003

Clinician Administered PTSD Scale (CAPS-5) total symptom severity score and PTSD diagnostic status per Weathers et al. (2015)

PTSD Check List for DSM-5 (PCL-5)-  total score

Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) – total score

Data Analytic Strategy: 

1) Evaluate the trauma self IAT with a clinical sample 

RQ1a: Are baseline IAT scores correlated with baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5), trauma 
exposure (# traumatic life events on LEC), and depression (score on the PHQ-9)?
Strategy: Zero-order correlations between IAT scores, PTSD symptoms, LEC events, and Depression sxs

RQ1b. Do baseline IAT scores predict baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and depression (PHQ-9) after controlling for gender and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)? 
Strategy: Separate regression models for PTSD symptoms and depression; will review distribution of PTSD and depression scores to see if adjustments to models need to be made for the outcomes (i.e., negative binomial vs. normal; zero-inflation); models will include gender and trauma exposure as covariates

RQ1c: Do IAT scores at 1-month follow up (post-treatment IAT scores) differ as a function of whether or not individuals still meet criteria for PTSD or depression?
Strategy: Independent samples t-test on post-treatment IAT scores comparing individuals who do vs. do not meet criteria for PTSD (i.e., PCL-5 scores at or above vs. below 33) at post-treatment; regression model evaluating IAT scores as a function of whether individuals meet criteria for depression (i.e., PHQ-9 score at or above vs. below 10) at post-treatment, controlling for baseline depression scores


2) Evaluate baseline trauma self IAT scores as predictors of treatment response (# of CPT sessions needed to achieve good end-state functioning, where end-state functioning is determined by scores on PCL-5); treatment dropout; whether or not clients meet threshold for good end-state functioning at their final CPT session; end state functioning 1-month and 3-month follow up; 

RQ2a. Do baseline IAT scores predict response to CPT above and beyond baseline symptoms and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)?
Strategy:  
Separate regression model for each of the following outcomes, with baseline IAT as a predictor, controlling for baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and trauma exposure (LEC): 
- Dropout from treatment (Logistic regression)
- Good end-state functioning -- i.e., did the participant reach good end state functioning, yes/no, defined as PCL-5 score less than 19 (Logistic regression) 
- # of sessions needed to achieve good end-state functioning (Count regression)

Separate longitudinal multilevel models will be conducted for each of the following outcomes: 
- PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) at post-treatment, 1-month, and 3-month follow up
- depression symptoms (PHQ-9) at post-treatment, 1-month and 3-month follow up
A random intercept and slope for time will be tested. The multilevel models will include the following fixed effects (i.e., predictors): 
- time
- baseline IAT
- baseline values of outcome (PCL-5 or PHQ-9 for respective outcomes)
- trauma exposure (LEC)
A time-by-IAT interaction will be tested to evaluate if the slope after treatment differs as a function of baseline IAT. If this interaction is non-significant, it will be removed from the final model to reduce complexity and simplify interpretation of the main effects. 

3) Evaluate change in trauma self IAT scores as a function of treatment and whether predict changes in PTSD symptoms
RQ3a: How do IAT scores change following treatment?
Strategy:
i.	Dependent samples t-test comparing baseline and post-treatment IAT scores
ii.	Exploratory analysis with regression models predicting post-treatment IATs controlling for baseline IAT, treatment length (i.e., number of sessions completed), and dropout. An interaction between treatment length and dropout will be tested. 
  
RQ3b: Are changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) associated with changes in PTSD and depression over time (baseline, 1-month and 3-month follow up)?
Strategy:
Latent difference score models will be constructed for IAT scores and for PTSD symptoms and for depression symptoms; we will estimate correlations between latent differences for IATs and PTSD symptoms; in a separate model, we will estimate correlations between latent differences for IATs and depression symptoms. 
Note that if the latent difference score models cannot be estimated (e.g., fail to converge, model assumptions are not met), standardized residual change scores will be estimated for IAT, PTSD, and depression scores, and correlations between these change scores will be evaluated.

RQ3c: Do residual IAT scores (assessed at 1-month follow up) predict increased PTSD symptoms at 12 weeks?
Strategy: Evaluate 1-month IAT scores as predictor of 3-month follow up PTSD scores (PCL-5), controlling for baseline and 1-month PTSD scores, as well as baseline IAT scores; sample will only include treatment responders

registration_responses.q1: Evaluating Implicit Trauma Associations as Predictors of Treatment Response to Cognitive Processing Therapy for Active Duty Military Personnel
registration_responses.q2: Kristen P. Lindgren, Anna Jaffe, Jennifer Wachen
registration_responses.q3:
There is burgeoning interest in the role of implicit cognitive processes (i.e., cognitive processes that are fast, reflexive, and potentially less controllable) in psychopathology, particularly because these processes may predict different outcomes than do self-report and may be less vulnerable to demand effects than self-report measures. Further, theories of psychopathology, including theories of PTSD, posit that changes in implicit cognitions are crucial for the development and maintenance of psychopathology. While measures have been developed to assess implicit cognitions related to psychopathology, including PTSD, few studies have evaluated these cognitions in clinical samples and even fewer have evaluated changes in these cognitions over the course of interventions (see Teachman, Marker, & Smith-Janik, 2008, JCCP, for one of the rare exceptions). The proposed study will address gaps by evaluating implicit cognitions related to PTSD (i.e., implicit associations about the self and being traumatized, which we term implicit trauma associations) in a sample of active duty military who participated in a clinical trial of variable length Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT).

A measure of implicit trauma associations (the trauma self IAT) was validated in a previous study (Lindgren et al., 2013, JBTEP). Lindgren et al. found that the trauma self IAT had adequate psychometrics and predicted self-reported post-traumatic stress (PTS) symptoms even after controlling for trauma exposure and self-reported trauma-related cognitions among a sample recruited through the Project Implicit research website (a self-selected sample who self-reported a range of trauma exposure and PTS symptoms). Despite these promising findings with a non-clinical sample, there is a need for additional validation of a trauma-focused IAT and understanding of the role of implicit cognitions in treatment. First, we wish to understand whether individuals’ baseline trauma self IAT scores predict their response to PTSD treatment (in this case, variable-length CPT). Doing so in a sample that is receiving CPT is particularly opportune because a core aim of CPT is to help clients explicitly shift trauma-related cognitions about the self to be more adaptive (i.e., flexible, balanced, realistic).  We consider this question to be exploratory. On the one hand, we could imagine that a higher IAT score at baseline might predict worse response to treatment because it signifies a more rigid trauma self-concept (which may be less responsive to treatment) and greater PTSD severity. On the other hand, we could imagine that a higher IAT score at baseline might predict greater response to treatment because CPT might be an excellent match for individuals with this particular vulnerability and these individuals have greater room for improvement. Second, it is also important to evaluate whether trauma self IAT scores change as a function of the intervention and whether changes in IAT scores predict changes in PTSD symptoms. This will help determine the malleability of the implicit trauma associations and their sensitivity to or prediction of changes in symptoms. Finally, it is unknown whether residual implicit trauma associations following treatment (i.e., IAT scores at 1-month follow up) predict return of symptoms over time (i.e., 3-month f-up), an important question to determine whether the associations serve as a vulnerability marker for potential relapse.
registration_responses.q4:
RQ1a: Are baseline IAT scores correlated with baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5), general trauma exposure (# traumatic life events on LEC), military trauma exposure (DRRI scores) and depression (score on the PHQ-9)?
i.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will be positively correlated with PTSD symptoms (replicating Lindgren et al., 2013) and the PHQ-9 (novel)
ii.	Hypothesis: Consistent with Lindgren et al. (2013), IAT scores will not be significantly associated with general trauma exposure (# events on LEC) or military trauma exposure (DRRI)

RQ1b. Do baseline IAT scores predict baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and depression (PHQ-9), even after controlling for gender and trauma exposure (# events on LEC), which are established predictors of PTSD symptoms? 
iii.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will positively predict incremental variance in baseline PTSD symptoms (replicating Lindgren et al., 2013) 
iv.	Hypothesis: IAT scores will positively predict incremental variance in baseline depression symptoms 

RQ1c: Do IAT scores at 1-month follow up (post-treatment IAT scores) differ as a function of whether or not individuals still meet criteria for PTSD or depression
i.	Hypothesis: Post-treatment IAT scores will be lower among individuals who no longer (vs. still) meet criteria for PTSD 
ii.	Hypothesis: Post-treatment IAT scores will be lower among individuals who no longer (vs. still) meet criteria for depression

RQ2a. Do baseline IAT scores predict response to CPT above and beyond baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)?
i.	Exploratory (double-sided hypotheses are offered): 
- Higher IAT scores (i.e., stronger traumatized-me associations) may predict worse treatment outcomes because individuals may have more rigid trauma self-concept and PTSD symptoms
- Higher IAT scores may predict better treatment response because CPT may be a good match for individuals with this vulnerability


RQ3a: How do IAT scores change following treatment?
i.	Hypothesis: IAT scores at 1-month follow up will be significantly lower than IAT scores at baseline
ii.	Exploratory: Evaluate whether changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) vary as a function of treatment length.  One might expect smaller decreases for those who were in treatment longer b/c those individuals took longer to respond to treatment. Alternatively, one might expect larger decreases b/c those individuals had more exposure to cognitive restructuring targeting negative beliefs about the self in relation to traumatic events, which could lead to larger decreases in trauma self IAT scores.   

RQ3b: Do changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) predict changes in PTSD and depression over time (baseline, 1-month, 3-month follow up)?
iii.	Hypothesis: Reductions in IAT scores will be associated with reductions in PTSD symptoms and depression

RQ3c: Do residual IAT scores (i.e., IAT scores at 1-month follow up) predict increased PTSD symptoms at 12 weeks?
i.	Hypothesis: Higher 1-month IAT scores will be associated with greater increases in PTSD symptoms from 1-month to 3-month follow up

registration_responses.q13: The ultimate N for the trial was 130. Data collection was smaller than originally planned (targeted N was 200) due to delays in data collection, which stemmed from delayed IRB approvals. It was determined that a smaller sample size would allow the trial research team to answer their research questions (see rationale below), so the funding agency agreed to a reduction in proposed sample size.
registration_responses.q14: Our sample size was determined based on power analyses for the larger clinical trial. For an analysis of variance comparing four groups of roughly equal size (early completers [< 12 sessions], normal completers [12 sessions], late completers [> 12 sessions], and non-responders [24 sessions without research good end state]), power with total N = 130 is .80 if Cohen’s f = .30, slightly larger than his convention for a “medium” effect. Survival regression analysis has power = .80 to detect a hazard ratio of 1.75, representing a different in recovery rates of about 15-20%.

registration_responses.q12.question:
All diagnostic clinical interviews were conducted by an independent evaluator (IE). IEs participated in four stages of training: relevant readings, didactic instruction with an expert in the field, mock interviews with co-workers, and co-rating exercises with previously taped assessments. After the completion of training, all IEs engaged in weekly calibration exercises to ensure that they continued to meet high quality standards. Any drift in scoring (i.e., failure to match decisions about PTSD diagnosis or a discrepancy in total score with the trainers) was brought to the attention of the IE so that the problem can be corrected in future assessments. 

Aside from the weekly administration of the PCL-5, DSI-SS, TRGI, and the PHQ-9, longer assessments, including diagnostic assessments and secondary measures, occurred prior to treatment, and 1 month and 12 weeks after the final therapy session. The assessment measures consisted of a battery of measures that have been used in the STRONG STAR Multidisciplinary Research Consortium studies to fully assess and appreciate complex symptomatology in this patient population, plus a number of study-specific measures. 

One of the original trial outcome variables was the distribution of the number of sessions needed to reach good end-state functioning, and the number of participants who never reached that goal. Any participant who stopped treatment early due to reaching good end-state was considered a treatment completer. If participants stopped prior to reaching a good end-state, they were considered “treatment drop-outs” unless they reached 24 sessions, at which time they would be considered non-responders. Participants were considered “treatment drop-outs” after two weeks of missed sessions without contacting their therapist. Regardless, all participants were asked to continue with assessment at 1 month and 12-weeks after they dropped out of treatment, so they only were considered a “study drop-out” if they stopped completing assessments.

Data Analytic Strategy: 

1) Evaluate the trauma self IAT with a clinical sample 

RQ1a: Are baseline IAT scores correlated with baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5), trauma 
exposure (# traumatic life events on LEC), and depression (score on the PHQ-9)?
Strategy: Zero-order correlations between IAT scores, PTSD symptoms, LEC events, and Depression sxs

RQ1b. Do baseline IAT scores predict baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and depression (PHQ-9) after controlling for gender and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)? 
Strategy: Separate regression models for PTSD symptoms and depression; will review distribution of PTSD and depression scores to see if adjustments to models need to be made for the outcomes (i.e., negative binomial vs. normal; zero-inflation); models will include gender and trauma exposure as covariates

RQ1c: Do IAT scores at 1-month follow up (post-treatment IAT scores) differ as a function of whether or not individuals still meet criteria for PTSD or depression?
Strategy: Independent samples t-test on post-treatment IAT scores comparing individuals who do vs. do not meet criteria for PTSD (i.e., PCL-5 scores at or above vs. below 33) at post-treatment; regression model evaluating IAT scores as a function of whether individuals meet criteria for depression (i.e., PHQ-9 score at or above vs. below 10) at post-treatment, controlling for baseline depression scores


2) Evaluate baseline trauma self IAT scores as predictors of treatment response (# of CPT sessions needed to achieve good end-state functioning, where end-state functioning is determined by scores on PCL-5); treatment dropout; whether or not clients meet threshold for good end-state functioning at their final CPT session; end state functioning 1-month and 3-month follow up; 

RQ2a. Do baseline IAT scores predict response to CPT above and beyond baseline symptoms and trauma exposure (# events on LEC)?
Strategy:  
Separate regression model for each of the following outcomes, with baseline IAT as a predictor, controlling for baseline PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and trauma exposure (LEC): 
- Dropout from treatment (Logistic regression)
- Good end-state functioning -- i.e., did the participant reach good end state functioning, yes/no, defined as PCL-5 score less than 19 (Logistic regression) 
- # of sessions needed to achieve good end-state functioning (Count regression)

Separate longitudinal multilevel models will be conducted for each of the following outcomes: 
- PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) at post-treatment, 1-month, and 3-month follow up
- depression symptoms (PHQ-9) at post-treatment, 1-month and 3-month follow up
A random intercept and slope for time will be tested. The multilevel models will include the following fixed effects (i.e., predictors): 
- time
- baseline IAT
- baseline values of outcome (PCL-5 or PHQ-9 for respective outcomes)
- trauma exposure (LEC)
A time-by-IAT interaction will be tested to evaluate if the slope after treatment differs as a function of baseline IAT. If this interaction is non-significant, it will be removed from the final model to reduce complexity and simplify interpretation of the main effects. 

3) Evaluate change in trauma self IAT scores as a function of treatment and whether predict changes in PTSD symptoms
RQ3a: How do IAT scores change following treatment?
Strategy:
i.	Dependent samples t-test comparing baseline and post-treatment IAT scores
ii.	Exploratory analysis with regression models predicting post-treatment IATs controlling for baseline IAT, treatment length (i.e., number of sessions completed), and dropout. An interaction between treatment length and dropout will be tested. 
  
RQ3b: Are changes in IAT scores (from baseline to 1-month follow up) associated with changes in PTSD and depression over time (baseline, 1-month and 3-month follow up)?
Strategy:
Latent difference score models will be constructed for IAT scores and for PTSD symptoms and for depression symptoms; we will estimate correlations between latent differences for IATs and PTSD symptoms; in a separate model, we will estimate correlations between latent differences for IATs and depression symptoms. 
Note that if the latent difference score models cannot be estimated (e.g., fail to converge, model assumptions are not met), standardized residual change scores will be estimated for IAT, PTSD, and depression scores, and correlations between these change scores will be evaluated.

RQ3c: Do residual IAT scores (assessed at 1-month follow up) predict increased PTSD symptoms at 12 weeks?
Strategy: Evaluate 1-month IAT scores as predictor of 3-month follow up PTSD scores (PCL-5), controlling for baseline and 1-month PTSD scores, as well as baseline IAT scores; sample will only include treatment responders

name.value:
Real World vs. Online Behaviors

This study will investigate the prevalence of digital self-harm in a sample of undergraduate freshmen at a large, Midwestern university.

sample.value: A correlation a priori power analysis was run to determine the sample size for this study. The software G*Power was used for this calculation. The input parameters for the power analysis was: one-tailed, effect size of 0.1, ɑ error probability of 0.05, and a Power of 0.95. The output parameters determined that a sample size of 1073 would be necessary to achieve these input parameters.

analyses.value:
Correlations will examine the relationship between personality traits and self-reported engagement in digital self-harm, the relationship between traditional forms of self-harm and digital self-harm, as well as the relationship between personality traits and self-reported engagement in traditional forms of self-harm.

A regression model for digital self-harm will be examined, based on findings from the correlational analyses.

outliers.value: To define outliers, the following data analysis will be conducted. First, descriptive statistics will reveal problematic outliers via scatterplots, box plots, and z-scores. Outliers will be removed (only if less than 5% of data), then descriptives will be conducted again, and compared, to the original exploration. If less than 5%, and the data is improved, the outliers will remain deleted. If more than 5%, then only the extreme outliers (>3.29 z-score) will be examined and deleted. Data transformation will not occur.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variables are:
- Five-Factor Model personality characteristics.
-- This will be measured using a short-form measure of the Five Factor Borderline Inventory.
- The prevalence of self-harm and digital self-harm
- For individuals who report engaging in the behavior, what are the functions of self-harm and digital self-harm
-- Both prevalence and function will be assessed using an adapted version of the Functional Assessment for Self-Mutilation
- The types of digital self-harm that individuals engage in
-- This will be measured using an adapted version of the Cyberbullying Deviancy Scale

conditions.value:
There will be the following 3 conditions:
- Engaged in self-harm, but not digital self-harm
- Engaged in digital self-harm, but not self-harm
- Engaged in both self-harm and digital self-harm

hypothesis.value:
There are several hypotheses being tested in this study. They are as follows:
- H1: Individuals who engage in traditional forms of NSSI are more likely to engage in digital self-harm.
- H2: Individuals who engage in digital self-harm will score higher on all facets of Neuroticism, and lower on certain facets of Agreeableness and Conscientiousness.
- H3: Individuals who engage in digital self-harm will report higher intrapersonal reinforcement functioning than interpersonal reinforcement functioning.

attributes.title: Activity-based Therapy Interventions for People Living with Spinal Cord Injury or Disease Across the Continuum of Care: A Scoping Review Protocol
attributes.description: A systematic scoping review will be completed to identify the characteristics and types of ABT that individuals with SCI/D participate in across the continuum of care (i.e. acute care, rehabilitation and community). The information gained from the systematic scoping review will be used to inform the quantitative Delphi rounds. The review will follow the Joanna Briggs Institute’s guidelines for systematic scoping reviews. The systematic scoping methodology was selected as we will follow a rigorous and systematic review process, while pursuing a broadly defined research question.

q2.value: Anita Kaiser, Katherine Chan, Kristin Musselman

q3.value: A systematic scoping review will be completed to identify the characteristics and types of ABT that individuals with SCI/D participate in across the continuum of care (i.e. acute care, rehabilitation and community). The review will follow the Joanna Briggs Institute’s guidelines for systematic scoping reviews. The systematic scoping methodology was selected as we will follow a rigorous and systematic review process, while pursuing a broadly defined research question.
