question.value: Systematic scoping review of activity-based therapies in individuals with spinal cord injury or disease across the continuum of care

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The primary and secondary review questions have been developed considering the relevant population, concept and context. The population will be adults (i.e. individuals aged >16 years) with acute, sub-acute or chronic SCI/D due to traumatic or non-traumatic causes. The concept of interest is activity-based therapy (ABT), defined as interventions that target activation of the neuromuscular system below the level of the lesion with the goal of retraining the nervous system to recover a specific motor function. The context is the continuum of care after SCI/D; acute care, inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation, and community-based programs, with the latter including private and non-profit clinics and home programs.
We will complete the three-step search method outlined by the Joanna Briggs Institute. First, we will complete an initial limited search of a few relevant databases, such as Medline. Words contained in the relevant titles and abstracts, along with the index terms used to describe relevant articles, will be noted. For example, some relevant articles may not use the term ABT, but another term such as locomotor training or exercise-based neurorecovery program. Second, a search using the identified keywords and index terms will be completed for all included databases: Medline, Embase, Emcare, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systatic Reviews, and PsycINFO. No date, language or study design restrictions will be imposed. Third, the reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for additional relevant studies.
The population, concept and context will guide the development of inclusion and exclusion criteria a priori; however, the criteria may be refined throughout the screening process. Two team members will independently review the returned titles and abstracts. Conflicts will be resolved by a third team member. The same process will be followed for the review of full text articles. A narrative description of the search decision process and a search decision flowchart will be produced.

q13.value: Not applicable for a systematic scoping review.

question.value: Not applicable for a systematic scoping review.
Not applicable for a systematic scoping review.
The research team will produce a qualitative synthesis of the review results, which will include frequency counts and descriptive statistics.

Data will be extracted from included articles and charted according to key themes. A charting table will be created as the review protocol is developed and subsequently refined as the review progresses. Example extraction fields include: author, year of publication, aim of study, study design, demographic (e.g. sex, gender) and injury characteristics of participants, type of ABT, frequency and duration of ABT, technology used to support ABT, outcome measures used, outcomes of ABT program, etc. The research team will produce a qualitative synthesis of the review results.

q22.value: Records will be excluded based on the following criteria: i) animal studies; ii) participants are under 16 years of age; iii) records are conference abstracts, books, or are reviews that don't provide original data; iv) ABT is only used above the level or lesion of injury or on areas not affected by the injury; v) single session of ABT.

q23.value: All available data for each included study will be extracted. Authors will be contacted to provide any missing data.

q24.value: We will pursue exploratory analysis of the relationships between sex/gender and participation in ABT, if these data are available in the included studies.

registration_responses.q8.question: Systematic scoping review of activity-based therapies in individuals with spinal cord injury or disease across the continuum of care
registration_responses.q12.question:
The primary and secondary review questions have been developed considering the relevant population, concept and context. The population will be adults (i.e. individuals aged >16 years) with acute, sub-acute or chronic SCI/D due to traumatic or non-traumatic causes. The concept of interest is activity-based therapy (ABT), defined as interventions that target activation of the neuromuscular system below the level of the lesion with the goal of retraining the nervous system to recover a specific motor function. The context is the continuum of care after SCI/D; acute care, inpatient and outpatient rehabilitation, and community-based programs, with the latter including private and non-profit clinics and home programs.
We will complete the three-step search method outlined by the Joanna Briggs Institute. First, we will complete an initial limited search of a few relevant databases, such as Medline. Words contained in the relevant titles and abstracts, along with the index terms used to describe relevant articles, will be noted. For example, some relevant articles may not use the term ABT, but another term such as locomotor training or exercise-based neurorecovery program. Second, a search using the identified keywords and index terms will be completed for all included databases: Medline, Embase, Emcare, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systatic Reviews, and PsycINFO. No date, language or study design restrictions will be imposed. Third, the reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for additional relevant studies.
The population, concept and context will guide the development of inclusion and exclusion criteria a priori; however, the criteria may be refined throughout the screening process. Two team members will independently review the returned titles and abstracts. Conflicts will be resolved by a third team member. The same process will be followed for the review of full text articles. A narrative description of the search decision process and a search decision flowchart will be produced.

registration_responses.q18.question: The research team will produce a qualitative synthesis of the review results, which will include frequency counts and descriptive statistics.
registration_responses.q19.question: Data will be extracted from included articles and charted according to key themes. A charting table will be created as the review protocol is developed and subsequently refined as the review progresses. Example extraction fields include: author, year of publication, aim of study, study design, demographic (e.g. sex, gender) and injury characteristics of participants, type of ABT, frequency and duration of ABT, technology used to support ABT, outcome measures used, outcomes of ABT program, etc. The research team will produce a qualitative synthesis of the review results.
